text: an organization called the oil spill
recovery Institute based in Cordova
Alaska was really formed as a
partnership uh between not for-profit
interests government and um the oil
companies after the Exxon vales spill
now what they were focused on was how do
you clean up oil spills in subarctic
Waters which is required a kind of a
different way of thinking oil in
subarctic Waters gets so cold it's
almost like a solid you can't pump it so
what most people don't realize is that
there are still something like 880,000
barrels of oil um off of Prince William
sound off the coast of Alaska that still
haven't been cleaned up from the Exon
Valdez spill so um you know in the last
couple of years I think after really
years of trying to figure out how to get
the oil out and running up against this
problem of very very viscous almost
solid oil um they put a challenge on the
innocent of network uh to try to find a
solution to this and in about 3 months
this was put out all over the world and
you know dozens and dozens of really
interesting Innovative Creative
Solutions came in but they awarded the
winning solution to a construction
engineer from the Midwest and what he
recognizes that keeping oil liquid in
cold Waters is not so different than
trying to keep cement liquid as I'm
pouring a foundation right again
organizations would have never thought
to look there that's the power of
diversity getting everybody involved in
solving a problem so it turns out what
he recommended is that um if you will
off-the-shelf construction equipment
that vibrates the cement keeps it liquid
with slight modifications could be used
in the barge systems that are really
trying to pump the oil off the bottom of
the sound so they're doing that now and
what's most exciting about this um for
me is the follow-up that was a $20,000
prize and this gentleman John Davis
flies himself to Cordova Alaska to using
the prize money to meet the people he
was helping and now he's doing pro bono
work for them and the oil spill recovery
Institute now runs challenges routinely
over innocentive they call innocentive
their virtual laboratory we are their
laboratory but the real moral of story
for me is this he didn't do it for the
$20,000 he did it to make a difference
in the world and that passion is
probably one of the most important
currencies you can imagine
